Get started

Resources

Automated Machines

3D Printer

A process for making a physical object from a three-dimensional digital model, typically by laying down many successive thin layers of a material.

TL houses 4 such 3D printers including a high-precision resin 3D printer.

Laser Cutter

A prototyping and manufacturing tool used primarily by engineers, designers, and artists to cut and etch into flat material.

A bed of size 6' x 4' is present at TL which has been extensively used for materials like aluminum, acrylic, medium-density fibreboards and many others.

CNC Machines

Computer numerical control (CNC) Machine uses numerical data to control a machine. CNC machines rely on a system of three linear and three rotational axes in order to calculate the motion and position of machine components and workpieces.

Wood & Metal Working

Milling Machine

Milling is the cutting operation that removes metal by feeding the work against a rotating, cutter having single or multiple cutting edges. Flat or curved surfaces of many shapes can be machined by milling with good finish and accuracy.

Lathe Machine

a machine tool that rotates a workpiece about an axis of rotation to perform various operations such as cutting, sanding, knurling, drilling, deformation, facing, and turning, with tools that are applied to the workpiece to create an object with symmetry about that axis.

Power Tools

A power tool is a tool that is actuated by an additional power source and mechanism other than the solely manual labor used with hand tools. The most common types of power tools use electric motors

Electrical Section

Soldering Station

Soldering is one of the most fundamental skills needed to dabble in the world of electronics. The two go together like peas and carrots.

DSO, Power Sources & AFG

The main purpose of an oscilloscope is to graph an electrical signal as it varies over time. Most scopes produce a two-dimensional graph with time on the x-axis and voltage on the y-axis.

Electronics

Tinkerers' Laboratory has lots of cool electronics like sensors, Arduino boards, RaspberyPis, ESP32s, several programmable ICs and boards.

In addition, these items can be issued to work on projects at home!

Projects

Our Projects

ITSP

EMO TV

As the name suggests, EmoTv is capable of interacting with a person and determine his current mood.

Read More

Technovation

CNC tube processing machine

A machine for steel structure fabrication industry, to perform multiple machining operations like cutting, notching, holes and slotting at a time.

Read More

ITSP

H.A.N.C.O

H.A.N.C.O. is an IoT device developed with a vision to become a dedicated personal AI assistant.

Read More

ITSP

OPTIKA

The project Optika makes surrounding of a visually impaired person more friendly by installing a lot of very helpful features on a raspberry pi.

Read More

Technovation

Hot Wire CNC (RC plane wing cutter)

This device cuts a desired airfoil shape wing out of the thermocol block and is fully automatic. User will have to provide the airfoil data file.

Testimonials

From the pen of our Alumni

It is a platform where they can transform their idea into product. Other labs have many issues like permissions but this is a lab for students run by students. Everything is available there so that they come with an idea and go out with a product. Initially, thought that they didn't want to push students to get a product and let TL use as a space and eventually after few years products will come out of tl.

Ashima Mittal

STAB O.C. 2013-14

From the first test drive of the XLR8 bot to the regular trips over the years, TL had been a frequent pit stop. The broad range of tools, all available at the same place, is a blessing for any team, working on hardware projects. Technicians are always around to help with the heavy equipment, helping us push limits of what we can build. TL's managing team, over the years, has built this encouraging environment, bringing together experienced alumni and motivated students. I wish them the best, for the future.

Aniruddha Ranade

Project Manager, Student Satellite Program, IIT Bombay 2018-20

I have been using the Tinkerers’ Laboratory since my first year, and I couldn’t be more grateful. Every Project that I have worked on has had a portion (or even the entire thing) completed in TL, from brainstorming to actual building. It isn’t just the availability of nearly every piece of equipment I needed, it’s also the community surrounding the lab. Help and guidance is there whenever I need it.

Savneek Bhatia

Institute Aeromodelling Club Secretary 2019-20

At times when I find myself unoccupied, Tinkerers Laboratory is the place where I will be found tinkering around with devices or machines. In case I happen to script the story of my institute life in no way possible can I keep Tinkerers' Laboratory out of it. Tinkerers' Laboratory has a lot to offer. I not only found the resources required to build any project but also a great community to interact and tinker around with. The necessity of such a facility was clear to me when I had to struggle to get a simple job done while the lab was closed. The kind of freedom I got to get my hand into operating various machines and building my ideas into shape has been amazing. If asked for I would describe this place as a necessity that must be accessible to growing engineers.

Shubham Agrawal

Manager, Electronics and Robotics Club 2020-21

Tinkerers’ Laboratory (aka TL) has been my second home at the Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay (1st being my room)! I had heard about the one of a kind student-run 24*7 open lab, Tinkerers’ Lab at Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, before I had entered the Institute. I am a big hardware person and started dabbling with power tools and electronics when I was in school. Stepping into TL for the first time was like a holy grail of hardware unlocked for me! Looking at a whole bunch of power tools,ranging from electric drill to jigsaws and all the electrical and mechanical components in the nicely arranged shelves, I was already having ideas floating in my mind on how and what to build! During the first year, TL provided me space and tools to build an electric car, an RC plane, and a quadcopter. The 3D printers came in TL during my 2nd year, and I couldn’t be more excited to learn more about it. One of my projects involved designing a chemical engineering lab experiment, and the 3D printing machine in TL came in handy for printing the necessary parts.My junior year in the Institute provided me with an opportunity to contribute to TL and helping it be a platform for speakers working in the field of technology to visit and share their knowledge with the students. As a Secretary of the Aeromodelling club, I invited speakers working on something as small as toy gliders to leaders in the field of commercial aviation. Tinkerers’ Lab also provided me as a platform to promote the spirit of “Social Entrepreneurship” in the Institute by initiating “Rural and Agricultural Projects” in association with the CTARA department and UNICEF. Looking back, I can say that, Tinkerers’ Lab has not been just a lab with tools but a canvas to express me onto it!

Yash Samriya

Institute Aeromodelling Club Secretary 2018-19

Many of my finest memories as an engineer in the institute were made here. Be it pulling out all-nighters for XLR8, RC Plane or designing a life follower in my freshmen year, every experience is etched very deep in my heart. It’s the closest to a place that allows you to realize that Tinkerer’s image one has in his/her mind before setting afoot at IIT Bombay. I have been privileged enough to get an opportunity to serve as the secretary for Tinkerers’ Lab and I still cherish the feeling of enabling others to realize the Tinkerer within oneself. Tinkerer’s Lab has always played some part in every project be it hobby or academic that I have done. It was always fun to have a lab open 24 hours to work on your ideas and I would say Tinkerers’ lab has played a key role in my journey to becoming an engineer

Mookund Sureka

Institute Tinkerers' Laboratory Secretary 2017-18

I remember vividly the first time I went to TL for soldering some connector pins for our RC plane in my first semester at IITB, sometime around midnight. I was fascinated to see how a single place in the whole of the academic area nearby was buzzing with enthusiastic people all working on something or the other. At that time I didn't realise how important a purpose TL was serving, facilitating people to work at any time with whatever they want all without any questions asked or permissions required. For me, TL quickly became a go-to place whenever I wanted to do any tinkering, a few times even just to chill out. TL not only provided a platform for us to work in a free environment but it also facilitated us with our academics. I still remember how for the first time in my life I had seen a 3D printer at TL and later the same 3D printer was used to fabricate major components of our research project and this is just one example out of many. The carefree environment of TL is like the early days of an infant where it just goes about exploring and experiencing everything by putting it in its mouth. Similarly, the hands-on learnings and the little mistakes made while tinkering at TL has now seasoned us to become confident and successful players professionally. I can continue to write about TL but any number of words won't be able to sum up my experience. Tinkerers' Laboratory aka TL is one of the best things to happen to IIT Bombay and I hope that it will continue to be the same for IITB and become a role model for others as well.

Naman Gupta

Institute Tinkerers' Laboratory Secretary

Tinkerers’ Lab (TL) has played a very pivotal role in my life@IITB. I think idea of TL is so awesome. Working in TL fulfilled the conception I had while preparing for JEE, about how engineering at the Indian Institute of Technology ought be. Inspired, I believed that I was uniquely positioned to lead TL.

Chirag Shetty

STAB OC 2015-16

Our counterparts in US and Europe learn to build and tinker with systems from an early age. That gives them an edge when we compete with them in our professional lives. Innovators like Steve Jobs of Apple and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook developed their innovative ideas while experimenting as students, whereas we at IIT usually learn how to excel within confined bounds of curriculum and examination system. I believe that to be relevant in technology game, IITs have to meet the challenge of how to motivate their students to build things, to take initiatives and to learn to innovate by building and Tinkerers' Lab(TL) will play an important role in that.

Mr. Hemant Kanakia

a 1975 batch alumnus of the institute and a successful entrepreneur based in USA
